dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High overhead shot looking down on the Pacific Ocean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDE ON a plume of black smoke rising high into the air. CLOSER ON a 1965 Ford Galaxy engulfed in flames. DOROTHEA (55, short grey hair, Amelia Earhart androgyny) (15, New-Wave/Punk) jog their shopping cart toward the co stunned to find their car in flames. Dorothea looks at th then at her son Jamie, concerned. People run for help. Si the background.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That was my husband’s Ford Galaxy. We drove Jamie home from the hospital in that car.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My mom was 40 when she had me. Everyone told her she was too old to be a mother.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I put my hand through the little window, and he’d squeeze my finger, and I'd tell him life was very big, and unknown;

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And she told me that there were animals and sky and cities,

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Music, movies. He’d fall in love, have his own children, have passions, have meaning, have his mom and dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When they got divorced, my father moved back east and left the car with us. He calls on birthdays and Christmas. Last time I felt close to him was on my birthday in 1974, he bought me mirrored sunglasses. I saw the president fall down the stairs, and I threw up on the 2.

dialogues.speaker: ARCADE
dialogues.text: carpet. INT. DOROTHEA’S LIVING ROOM Dorothea and Jamie slouch on couch, with “JEEVES” the cat watching her favorite film CASABLANCA.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Since then it’s just been us. Track in on television playing the famous end of the film

dialogues.speaker: RICK / BOGART
dialogues.text: You're getting on that plane.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA / BERGMAN
dialogues.text: I don’t understand what about you?

dialogues.speaker: RICK / BOGART
dialogues.text: I'm staying here with him till the plane get’s safely away.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA / BERGMAN
dialogues.text: No Richard, what has happened to you, last night....

dialogues.speaker: THERE. DOROTHEA IS GREGARIOUS WITH THE FIREMEN WHO WORK A
dialogues.text: JAMIE WATCHES, STILL STUNNED, LIFE’S SURPRISES.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: Listen, Captain. I am having a party tonight, it’s my birthday actually, and I would like you to drop by so I can feed you

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s not necessary Mrs. Fields.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: It’s Dorothea - no, I insist, please? That way I can thank you. She hands her address to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie and Dorothea sit on a side bumper of a fire truck, movement around them. They look small, sit close, groceri at their feet. Dorothea watches Jamie. The fire scared her. She looks vulnerable.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: That was a beautiful car.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Mom, it smelled like gas and overheated all the time, and it was just old... Dorothea’s surprised, she didn’t know they felt so differently about the car.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: (What?) Well it wasn’t always old. Dorothea goes to touch his hair. He bends away from her h Jamie turns to his mom, trying to explain the contemporar world to her.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: You know, when the firemen come, people don’t usually invite them over for dinner. Camera tracks away, revealing them like refugees in the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: Yeah? Why not?

dialogues.speaker: MAIN TITLE ON BLACK
dialogues.text: INT. MARY’S THERAPY PLACE - DAY Camera pans across teen therapy girl (IMPROVISE THERAPY TALK), sees a circle of 6 other teen girls having therapy lands on JULIE (17, Something subversive below her good looks) similarly bored. The therapist MARY, (40’s academi listens. Julie stares at Mary, criticality brewing inside her. EXT. OUTSIDE MARY’S OFFICE Julie lights up a cigarette, her real self, gets on her b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie smokes and rides her bike, her real self more on vi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ABBIE (28, Sophisticated NYC art-punk type) stands in gow OBGYN office, looking confused, vulnerable, but armed wit late 70's clunky Nikon camera. She studies her doctor put a swab into a tube, writing her name; she takes a photogr Turns and takes a photo of the room, her doctor is used t this. She watches an assistant come in and take the swab (and h future fate) in its plastic container away - go down the hall, and disappear around a corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The technician carries the little swab down the hall, ina clear plastic bag. INT. DOROTHEA’S SIDE DOOR Abbie walks in, looking lost, puts her bag down in the kitchen. INT. ABBIE’S ROOM Now in her room, Talking Heads playing loudly, her pain p and she begins to dance alone. EXT. DOROTHEA’S HOUSE Julie rides her bike past a line of old VWs and an old 30 Chevy. INT. DOROTHEA’S HOUSE Julie enters the house, walks towards WILLIAM (Mid 40's p hippie type).  5. William takes on a major job on his own (tearing down cei in entry way). Reveal that this is a big house, needing repair under serious renovations.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Oh, hey, sorry. Jamie’s not here right now. Julie walks past this. Follows the sound of music upstair INT. HALLWAY/ABBIE’S ROOM Julie can see Abbie dancing through a partially opened do Abbie captivates her, she walks towards the room, Abbie s her, snaps out of her dancing, turns off the record. Julie enters, Abbie’s still troubled by her OBGYN visit, Julie can’t really take her eyes off Abbie.

dialogues.speaker: ABBIE
dialogues.text: They’re not home. Abbie takes her picture.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Don't. That doesn’t stop Abbie. Not mean, just stubborn.

dialogues.speaker: ABBIE
dialogues.text: I'm taking pictures of everything that happens to me in a day.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: I don’t like having my picture taken. I didn’t happen to you. She takes another. INT. DOROTHEA’S KITCHEN AREA Dorothea and Jamie make their way to the kitchen with all groceries.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. William enters and helps them, Julie and Abbie enter a be later.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: Hi. She hands William a bag of groceries.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: You aren’t going to believe what happened.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Our car burst into flames in the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Seriously?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: You OK?

dialogues.speaker: ABBIE
dialogues.text: How did it happen?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: I don’t know, they said probably just something electrical. We walked out and it was just sitting there, on fire. Life’s surprises.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Oh man, I’m sorry. Everyone’s perplexed. William helps unload groceries. Julie and Jamie IMPROV in background.  7. DOROTHEA PULLS ABBIE ASIDE, LOOKS AT HER, ABBIE DOESN’T W TO SHARE.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: So, what happened?

dialogues.speaker: ABBIE
dialogues.text: They never tell you anything, I won't know for like a week. Dorothea gives her an encouraging look. ABBIE (CONT’D) I’m gonna be late on rent.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: That’s okay, Don’t worry about that.

dialogues.speaker: ABBIE
dialogues.text: Thanks. Abbie looks at Dorothea with love and admiration. INT. JAMIE’S BEDROOM - DAY Jamie lies flat on his bed. Julie’s next to him, processi earnestly worried for him.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: What if you had been in the car? He shrugs, gestures with his hand. She lays beside him on side. She traces a finger across his hair, his forehead, nose, chest, their hands touch.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t be here. You would’ve missed me?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: (Yeah) Don’t joke. She traces a finger across his hair, his forehead, nose, chest, their hands touch. He puts his hand on her bare kn starts to slide up her leg. She easily pulls his hand off

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was so much easier before you got all horny. He’s tried this before, but he is really just her friend. He leans away from her.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s not like you, don’t -

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Do it? She likes that she does it. He smiles, used to her love o being provocative. Then serious.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Friends can’t have sex and still be friends. She snuggles him again innocently, pressing her face into arm.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I like us like we are - OK?

dialogues.speaker: OK
dialogues.text: off screen, from far away. DOROTHEA O.S. Jamie ... Can you come help set up please?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Can my mom just chill out?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: She's compensating for her loneliness. INT. DOROTHEA’S ENTRY WAY William takes Dorothea to see the ceiling he worked on. S loves it. It’s pretty messed up. IMPROVISE ABOUT THE WORK DONE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorothea, all that is beautiful molding there.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: It is.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I want to continue that around the side.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: All right so we’re gonna have to re- match that, is that actually wood, or is that plaster?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No, the plaster is underneath it, the molding on the outside there is wood. It'll take some time... INT. DOROTHEA’S DINING ROOM - NIGHT Her party’s in full swing. An eclectic mix of people. 15 the regulars; construction guys, straight looking draftin men, a few women Dorothea’s age, and 4 firemen from befor People are all talking and drinking, eating and moving ar the room. WE CROSS BETWEEN MANY SHORT INTERWOVEN MOMENTS WITHIN THE PARTY. CAMERA MOVES WITH Dorothea showing the CHIEF a little of the house. William silently glides with them.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: It was built in 1905, the same family had it forever, but they lost all their money during the war, there was a fire - you should’ve been here for that. Anyway, so it was just a mess, they just let it fall apart. Then a bohemian inherited it in the 60’s, bunch of free spirits lived here, and they lost it to the bank.

dialogues.speaker: FIRE CHIEF
dialogues.text: It’s beautiful.  10.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: (I think so) I completely fell in love with it. CAMERA FINDS WILLIAM AND ABBIE, sitting on the couch talk

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: We’re connected to the dirt because we came from the dirt. The dirt is made of stars and star dust the same way we are, so when you put your hands into that dirt and feel the earth mother... She laughs. INT. DOROTHEA'’S KITCHEN Dorothea busily makes her famous angel food and strawberr messy pile of a cake. Jamie’s putting in the candles. William’s piling up the plates to take in.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: William, it looks as though I’m gonna be in need of a car. Do you think you have something cheap? Maybe that ‘49 deluxe?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I think we can work something out, maybe we’ll trade for rent or something.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: Sure. He takes the plates into the dining room. Dorothea finishes lighting the candles, to Jamie.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: OK, give me a minute, then come in. She trots off to the party - Jamie waits a minute then he in. INT. DOROTHEA’S DINING ROOM - DAY Jamie brings the cake into the dining room, applause, che she’s happy - blows out the candles.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My mom was born in 1924. When she was my age people drove in sad cars to sad houses with old phones, no money or food or televisions but the people were real.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When she was 16, the war broke out and she had to leave school.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Her dream was to be a pilot in the air force. She actually went to flight school. But the war ended before she was done.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She became the first woman to work in the Continental Can Company drafting room. Then she met my dad. Then I came. Then they got divorced. But people from her time never admit anything went wrong. 11.

dialogues.speaker: VISUALS
dialogues.text: 10. REPORTAGE OF 40’S ERA DRAFTING ROOMS.

dialogues.speaker: CUT FROM 40'S DRAFTING REPORTAGE TO
dialogues.text: INT. DOROTHEA’S DRAFTING ROOM — DAY Dorothea works and smokes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorothea and EIGHT YEAR OLD JAMIE are sitting at a bank d talking with a MANAGER.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: What do you mean?  12.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: He’s too young to have an account in his name only - little guy.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: He’s a person, not a half person, not some cute little guy, he has volition and autonomy and privacy and he needs a bank account. Can you do that for us?

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, he’s too young. INT. JAMIE’S SCHOOL - DAY Dorothea and 13 YEAR-OLD JAMIE are sitting in a school of being scolded by a principal type. He hands her a note, s resents this authority figure.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Jamie, you can’t just keep skipping school and making excuses.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: Well wait a minute, why not? Why can’t he skip school? If he has a legitimate need to be away?

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Then I need a legitimate real note from you with your real signature. Hands her Jamie’s forged note.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: Okay, wow, how did you forge my signature so well? INT. DOROTHEA’S 1977 HOUSE - DAY CUT TO: 12 year-old hands holding a check with Dorothea’s signature against a window, then placing the note over it tracing the signature.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's really ingenious. But, never forge someone's signature, or do something behind their back.  13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 12 year old Jamie walks in and hands a note to the secret CLOSE ON the note.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Please excuse Jamie from school this morning, he was doing volunteer work for the Sandinistas. The secretary looks incredulous, but files the note and l Jamie head to class. DIFFERENT DAY: Jamie walks in, hands over a note. CLOSE O note.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Please excuse Jamie from school this morning, he was involved in a small plane accident, fortunately he was not hurt. The secretary looks up at Jamie and files the note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William tries to teach Jamie how to help out around the h with Dorothea’s encouragement. IMPROVISE TALKING ABOUT RENOVATIONS.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: You're going to be in for a legendary surprise. It’s mahogany underneath. JAMIE V.O. She's always trying to bring a man into my life.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: This is probably Honduran mahogany, really fine grain... CUT TO Dorothea and Jamie whispering away from William.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: This is like, really boring, Hey watch it, he’s helping m he’s talking about wood and out, restore the house O.K.? stuff.  14. INT. DOROTHEA’S 1975 KITCHEN - MORNING - 1975

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She writes down her stocks every morning, 10 YEAR OLD Jamie’s and Dorothea’s backs as they’re hunch over the stock reports, writing down the day’s numbers.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE VISUALS
dialogues.text: She smokes Salems because 11. SALEMS 12. HER they're healthier, wears BIRKENSTOCKS 13. DOROTHEA Birkenstocks because she’s WORKS IN HOME OFFICE 14. contemporary. She read DOROTHEA READING ALONE IN BED Watership Down and learned SMOKING. how to carve rabbits out of wood. And she never dates a man for very long. INT. DOROTHEA’S FRONT DOOR / BACK TO DOROTHEA’S BIRTHDAY The partygoers are heading out, Dorothea saying her good- foreground Julie whispers with Jamie.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: See you later?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Just don’t hang out with that Chris guy anymore, okay? He’s a skeez and he’s kind of dumb.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Exactly.  15. Turns to Dorothea as she leaves,

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Happy birthday.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: Bye Julie. She leaves Jamie and Dorothea alone on the doorstep.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Stop.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Thinking you know everything that’s going on.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: Having your heart broken is a tremendous way to learn about the world. INT. DOROTHEA'’S KITCHEN - CONTINUOUS They’re alone now, doing the dishes together, he studies

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Do you think you’re happy, like as happy as you thought you’d be when you were my age?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: Seriously, you don’t just ask people questions like that.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: You're my mom.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: Especially your mom. Look, wondering if you’re happy is a great shortcut to being depressed.  16. He looks at her disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorothea is alone. Lost in thought. An ironing board in t background. Just smoking and thinking. Then, from above, plays. She looks up, in the direction of the sound. Rises INT. ABBIE’S ROOM - NIGHT Jamie and Abbie sit together, listening to The Raincoats Fairytale In The Supermarket. Abbie’s looking at the cove Jamie's looking through her other records. Dorothea appears in the doorway, observing her son, and h obvious love of this. She enters, sits down and listens w them, an awkward moment.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: ABBIE
dialogues.text: It’s The Raincoats. She nods awkwardly to the beat, trying to relate.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: Can’t things just be pretty?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: “Pretty” music’s used to hide how unfair and corrupt society is.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: Ah, okay so... they’re not very good, and they know that, right? He just looks at her - ‘why’re you still here’ - she look him confused by his pushing her away. Seriously curious.

dialogues.speaker: ABBIE
dialogues.text: Yea, it’s like they’ve got this feeling, and they don’t have any skill, and they don’t want skill, because it’s really interesting what happens when your passion is bigger than the tools you have to deal with it. It creates this energy that’s raw. Isn’t it great?  17. CU on Dorothea feeling like an outsider, lost. INT. DOROTHEA’S BEDROOM Dorothea sits at the edge of her bed, smoking and thinkin

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: My son was born in 1964.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA V.O. CONTD. VISUALS
dialogues.text: He grew up with a meaningless 1. VIET NAM BURNING ON war, with protests, with TELEVISION 2. 1968 PROTEST ON Nixon, with nice cars and TELEVISION 3. NIXON ON nice houses, computers, TELEVISION 4. CAR SALESMAN ON drugs, boredom. TV 5. FAST FOOD COMMERCIAL ON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie dances wildly alone, to punk music. DOROTHEA V.O. I know him less every day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie skateboards down San Leandro, free, like he’s flyin DOROTHEA V.O. He said it was just a game. EXT. MONTECITO RAMP AREA -— DAY Jamie watches other kids do “the fainting game”. One kid hyperventilates, another pulls on his diaphragm from behi The kid faints and gets up, everyone laughs. DOROTHEA V.O. You breathe real hard and another kid pulls on your diaphragm and you faint. Now Jamie tries it. He breathes heavily, kid pulls on his diaphragm from behind, FILM BEGINS TO SPEED UP, Jamie fai he falls, he doesn’t wake up.  18. DOROTHEA V.O. He said you’re supposed to come to a few seconds later, but it took Jamie almost a half an hour to wake up. Julie runs from the ramp where she’s been watching all th She tries to wake him, tell’s others to get help, she’s panicked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie runs for help.

dialogues.speaker: ALL IN FAST MOTION
dialogues.text: INT. ABBIE’S CAR - DAY Jamie is still unconscious, his head in Dorothea’s lap. S looks terrified. Abbie and Julie are there, William drive

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William runs, carries Jamie’s limp body into the hospital everyone follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOOKING DOWN ON Jamie. STILL IN FAST MOTION. They all watch nurses and doctors take his vitals. It’s a confusing blur.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: (Tech talk - he’s stable - We just have to wait - EKG) Nurses (Nurse tech talk, he’s stable) They turn to rush Jamie to a bed. A doctor takes Dorothea the arm.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Can you tell me what happened? A parent's wild guilt and fear on her face. NEARBY: Jamie’s on a gurney, put into a small screened-in area, still limp, unconscious, swarmed by nurses and tech  19. Abbie and Julie get swept-up in the screened off area. Th two would never be together if it weren’t for Dorothea an Jamie; Abbie, an older punk, Julie, a younger AP student. The girls watch nurses take off his shirt, put on EKG nod his body is limp, Abbie starts to silently cry, Julie too Dorothea finds Jamie’s screened in area. William sits politely outside. His concern is for Dorothea. NOW Behind the screen, DOROTHEA FREEZES when she sees the wires all over his bare chest. Abbie and Julie are squish into a corner. Dorothea moves around the nurses and technicians still working, she finds his hand, puts it in both of hers, presses her forehead against it. She takes his hand, like she did when he was a baby in th isolette, closes her eyes. JAMIE REGAINS CONSCIOUSNESS - disorientated and confused, clumsily tries to pull off the oxygen canula.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: He’s back. The nurses and doctor scramble around him, doing vitals, asking questions.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: What’s your name? Confused, but present.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Jamie... Jamie Fields. Dorothea looks on relieved but destroyed by this. FAST MOTION ENDS. INT. JAMIE’S HOSPITAL ROOM NIGHT Jamie's asleep in hospital bed, Dorothea sits next to him worried, touching his hair. She gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She exits his room, exhausted, she finds Julie and Abbie waiting in the hallway. This means a lot to Dorothea, she sit’s next to them.  20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie walks ahead going up the stairs. She walks behind, eying him. Her worry and fear rising, until she says...

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: Why did you do something so - stupid (dangerous).

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know mom, everyone was doing it. Escalating fear and anger with each line.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: So you just went along with it?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: It looked like fun.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: That’s just dumb. Why would you do something so stupid? Just following along? You know you almost died, right? He gets very defensive, feels attacked.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: Let’s talk about something else. William’s hurt. Julie’s buzzed with attention, can’t stop out.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: First time I had sex I was 14...

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Julie?!  85.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: I just decided one night I was going to lose my virginity, didn’t matter who. Jamie’s mad or protective, or both. He tries to stop her.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Can you chill out?

dialogues.speaker: ABBIE
dialogues.text: Let her talk.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: I picked this guy I didn’t know at a party, had fairly painful sex in his van parked in the street, just spit in his hand for lubrication, got home in time for my curfew. The carpet in his van smelled like spilled bong water. The men are awkwardly mute. Julie wakes up to what she’s surprised she hurt Jamie. Dorothea’s had it with these gi well.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: Okay, lets call it a night. C’mon guys. Dorothea herds the men from the table. Abbie examines Jul Julie's finally become interesting to her, sympathetic. Dorothea pushes them out of the living room.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: Show’s over girls. Everyone's leaving the party. INT. DOROTHEA'’S KITCHEN Abbie helps Dorothea clean up. It’s hard for Abbie to get Dorothea’s attention.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: Jamie, we need to, there’s a lot of stuff happening, I’d like to know what’s going on with you. This has all been a lot for us to deal with. She just lost him, he makes an exasperated gesture.  86.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I'm dealing with everything, you are dealing with nothing. He leaves, wildly pissed. Abbie and Dorothea share an ang look themselves, Abbie leaves. Reveal William was there, looks disappointed, avoids Dorothea. INT. JAMIE’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Julie comes through the window. He’s angry with her, sitt on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Hey?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I can’t believe you told everyone all that.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: I can say what I want to say.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: They're just gonna think you’re some... they’re gonna get the wrong idea about you. That’s not like him, she’s surprised, hurt.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: (A slut?) Is that what you think? Jamie’s truly confused by it all.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: You can’t sleep here and just want to talk with me anymore. Pause, that really scares Julie.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Yea.  87.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I’m sorry. OK? She feels horrible, and surprised, reeling. Jamie’s silent.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let’s get out of here, like you said, let’s go up the coast. Just the two of us. Off Jamie, looking like he’s going to shut her down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorothea finds the note Jamie left.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mom. Julie and I took the car. We're taking a trip up the coast. Just to get away. You don’t need to worry about us.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. 101 FREEWAY
dialogues.text: Dorothea’s VW bug makes its way up the 101. Classic California coast. Half painted over “ART FAG” sti visible on the side of the car. Inside the car, Julie smo and drives, punk cassette on the radio. Jamie stares out the window, his arm around the back of h neck. They look like a couple in love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie and Jamie explore the rugged rocks along ocean. They sit on some rocks, the rough ocean down below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weeknight at the club, only the usual denizens are dancin After a beat we reveal Dorothea entering the punk club al She's not really looking for jamie, she’s looking for his world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie and Julie eye a skeezy middle aged man on his way i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me sir, maybe you’d buy us some wine coolers? You can keep the change. The man takes the money, walks in.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Strawberry, or anything berry.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. S.B. STREETS
dialogues.text: Dorothea smokes and drives - dealing with her frustration Then cops lights behind her. CUT TO: Cop asking her questions.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: What’s the matter?

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: You changed lanes in the intersection back there.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: Seriously, that’s all?

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Yes. I need to see your license. Dorothea’s anti-authority thing kicks in.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: Well what if I don’t have my license?

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: What’s your name, address and date of birth.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: Those are personal questions, I mean we've just met. What’s your name? Where do you live? Right? It’s a little forward. She looks at him mischievously.  89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie smokes in bed and undresses. Jamie comes in and sit on the bed. Something’s brewing in Julie. Jamie’s looking confused, out of body himself.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I love you. He tries to be sweet and caress her, she pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: I think I’m too close to you to have sex with you, it confuses me. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I can help you get over that.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: I don’t want to get over it.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Yeah you do.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: You're being like the other guys.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I don’t want to just, have sex with you, I want...you.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: But that’s like, your version of me, that’s not me... It’d be better if you just wanted sex... You are like the others, you just pretend to be all modern about it.  90. Jamie rises, hurt and angry, gets dressed.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Jamie? He doesn’t talk. He leaves in a rush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie exits the room, and takes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie hurriedly walks the streets of this sleepy town alo

dialogues.text: Dorothea waits on a bench, after being processed. Long sh the hall, Abbie walks up to her and sits by her. Dorothea mess and kind of sweaty looks at her confused, down the h can see William waiting patiently, not wanting to add to

dialogues.text: These people have no sense of humor.

dialogues.speaker: ABBIE
dialogues.text: Let’s get out of here. Abbie neatens Dorothea’s hair, tidies her up a little bit her arm and they walk out past the male cops, who don’t g the way, Abbie has to shoulder butt one as they pass, hol dignity together. INT. ABBIE’S CAR -— NIGHT Abbie drives her home. She’s exhausted, doesn’t want any judgement. INT. DOROTHEA’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Abbie helps Dorothea into bed, gets her a glass of water.

dialogues.speaker: ABBIE
dialogues.text: Having a kid seems like the hardest thing.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: How much you love the kid is the hardest thing. You’re just pretty screwed.  91. Abbie feels the loss of what she can’t have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie, strung out and tired is walking down a dirt road n agrarian field. As he walks, a group of 30 or so Latino m workers cross the road and the frame. They’re heading to are as young as Jamie it seems, he stops as they all cros none of them look at him. Two different worlds. INT. DOROTHEA’S KITCHEN - MORNING Dorothea enters, finds Abbie and William at the table. Sh them, not sure, mixed feelings, anger and vulnerability.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: Julie called, they’re in San Luis Obispo, but she can’t find him. She looks at them, more open and real.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: Will you guys please come with me? Up there?

dialogues.speaker: I/E. 101 FREEWAY
dialogues.text: William drives Dorothea and Abbie up the 101 freeway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful landscape, the Ford makes its way up the coast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Ford pulls up, Julie’s waiting, smoking. Dorothea com concerned. Julie’s totally torn up, she looks like she kn fucked up.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: Where is he? Julie points to the edge of the hotel, down by the oak tr To Julie’s surprise, Dorothea touches her sweetly.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: Thanks for calling me.  92.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorothea finds Jamie, alone, angry, at first not wanting her. They’ve both been up most the night, they both look walks away, she follows.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: Julie’s a really complicated woman. I’m impressed in a way, but that’s a lot to take on. He keeps walking, heads into the connecting vineyard. She him, he doesn’t look back, she follows. Catches up with h

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Aren’t you going to get Julie? To come talk with me?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: Jamie!

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: I thought they’d help. That stops him, changes him.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: It just seemed like you couldn’t deal with me anymore.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: Look. I wanted. I. I don’t want you to end up in the same place as me.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: Well, I wanted you to be happier. I just didn’t think I could do it by myself.  93.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Okay..I thought we were fine though, just me and you.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.text: Dorothea, Abbie, Julie, Jamie and William sitting in the eating take out dinner. JUMPS CUTS; Dorothea finds an old station, 30’s-40’s music plays. Dorothea teaches Jamie to dance, Abbie joins in, then Jul and William, they all find a partner. A small moment of grace between these 5 people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abbie, Julie and William are loaded up in Dorothea’s car, heading off. IMPROV GOODBYES. Dorothea and Jamie are alone now, they have to face each

dialogues.text: Maybe we don’t go back yet?

dialogues.text: I want to dye my hair. She's not really comfortable with that.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Well, yeah. Dorothea can’t relate, but wants to relate.  94.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie and Dorothea have a picnic.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Were you and dad ever in love?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: At first. Or maybe I was just supposed to be in love. Or scared that I’d never be in love. So I picked the best solution I had at the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUMP CUTS: Dorothea washes Jamie’s hair / rubs in the dye with the little plastic baggy over his head / washes it o his hair. She feels deep bittersweet heartbreak, loves hi understands him so little.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Are you lonely?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: Well, in my next life, I might marry Bogart, we’ll see.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: He's... dead.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: I’m talking about next life right? So he may be around, and we might meet and something might happen between us, OK?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: What about having that in the real world?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: This is no time to get rational sweetie, can you just go with this?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: O.K. - keep going.  95.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHEA
dialogues.text: He knows what I’m thinking, and what makes me laugh - he can really see me. And, you know he’s gonna do what he says he’s gonna do, so it’s easy.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: He sounds great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorothea drives. REVEAL that Jamie is on his skateboard hanging onto the passenger door, window down.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I thought that was just the beginning of a new relationship with her, where she'd really tell me stuff. But maybe it was never really like that again. Maybe that was it.

dialogues.text: I‘1l live with Dorothea for another year. Then I’1l open a pottery store in Sedona Arizona. EXT. WILLIAM’S POTTERY AREA: WILLIAM TALKS TO CAMERA.

dialogues.text: I will marry Laurie, a singer- songwriter. We'll get divorced in a year. Then I’1l meet Sandy, we will marry, and I will continue to do my pottery.

dialogues.text: My mom will meet Jim in 1983, they'll be a couple until she dies. On her birthday each year, he will buy her a trip on a biplane. INT. DOROTHEA’S LIVING ROOM: SHE AND JAMIE DANCING
